SAM-SAH

Apr 29, 2023 • Zhizhong Lu, Wenjian Liao

Rfam ID: RF01727 (SAM/SAH riboswitch)

Description

The SAM–SAH riboswitch is a conserved RNA structure in certain bacteria that binds S-adenosylmethionine (SAM) and S-adenosylhomocysteine (SAH) and is therefore presumed to be a riboswitch. SAM–SAH riboswitches do not share any apparent structural resemblance to known riboswitches that bind SAM or SAH. The binding affinities for both compounds are similar, but binding for SAH is at least somewhat stronger. SAM–SAH riboswitches are exclusively found in Rhodobacterales, an order of alphaproteobacteria. They are always found in the apparent 5' untranslated regions of metK genes, which encode the enzyme (Methionine adenosyltransferase) that synthesizes SAM. (from WIKi).


Gene association

Pathways for sulphate assimilation and biosynthesis of cysteine and methionine. SAM-SAH riboswitch (red bar) is involved in multiple gene regulation in the synthetic pathway[1].


Gene regulation

Model of SAM-SAH riboswitch sequential folding and translational control.[5].


Structure and Ligand recognition

2D representation

Left: Consensus sequence and secondary structure model for the SAM-SAH riboswitch. Right: Secondary structure depictions of the SAM-SAH riboswitch according to PDB ID:6ymm[5].


Document



3D visualisation

2.2-Å resolution crystal structure of an S-adenosylmethionine (SAM) riboswitch from thermoanaerobacter tengcongensis complexed with S-adenosylmethionine.SAM (shown in sticks) is labeled in red [5].
PDBe Molstar






Binding pocket

Left: Surface representation of the binding pocket of the SAM-SAH riboswitch generated from PDB ID:6YMM. S-adenosylmethionine (SAM) (shown in sticks) is labeled in red.Right: Hydrogen bonding between SAM and adjacent bases[5].


Ligand recognition

Chemical structures of various compounds used to probe the binding characteristics of the SAM-VI riboswitch[5].
